topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Distance is not immediately perceived by sight

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Distance is perceived mediately, by means of intervening ideas

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The ideas of sight and touch are entirely heterogeneous

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: What we call "seeing distance" is actually judging distance from visual signs

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The connection between visual ideas and distance is learned through experience

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Lines and angles drawn from objects to the eye are not themselves perceived

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Geometrical optics cannot explain how we perceive distance

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The mind does not calculate distances using optic angles

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Convergence of the eyes provides a sensation that suggests distance

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The strain of accommodation in the eye contributes to near-distance judgments

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Confusion or blurriness of an image serves as a sign of nearness

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Distinctness or clarity of an image serves as a sign of distance

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Faintness of appearance suggests greater distance

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Vigor or intensity of appearance suggests nearness

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The number of intermediate objects affects distance judgments

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: These various signs are combined in distance perception

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The connection between these signs and distance is arbitrary, not necessary

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Experience alone teaches us to interpret visual signs as indicating distance

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: A person born blind and made to see would not immediately perceive distance

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Such a person would initially see all objects as in the eye itself

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The Molyneux problem is answered negatively: a newly sighted person could not recognize shapes

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visible ideas and tangible ideas are specifically distinct

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: A visible square and a tangible square are different ideas entirely

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: They are called by the same name only through custom and association

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The connection between visual and tangible ideas resembles that between words and meanings

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visual ideas function as a natural language signifying tangible ideas

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: This language is universal to all sighted creatures

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The Author of Nature established this correlation for our benefit

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Light and colors are the immediate and proper objects of sight

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Extension and figures are perceived by sight only mediately

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visible extension differs in kind from tangible extension

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: There is no abstract general idea of extension common to sight and touch

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Abstract general ideas are impossible

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: All ideas are particular and determinate

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Minimum visibles exist: the smallest perceivable visual points

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visible extension is composed of finite collections of minima visibilia

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Minimum tangibles exist: the smallest perceivable tactile points

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Tangible extension is composed of finite collections of minima tangibilia

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: A minimum visible is not the same thing as a minimum tangible

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The two minima are heterogeneous in nature

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: One minimum visible may correspond to varying tangible magnitudes

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Magnitude is not immediately perceived by sight

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visible magnitude and tangible magnitude are entirely distinct

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: What we call the "real" magnitude of an object is its tangible magnitude

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visible magnitude is merely a sign suggesting tangible magnitude

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The same visible magnitude may signify different tangible magnitudes

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Different visible magnitudes may signify the same tangible magnitude

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Judgments of tangible magnitude from visible signs are learned

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: A near object and a far object producing the same visible magnitude appear differently

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The difference is due to associated ideas, not immediate perception

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Situation or spatial position is not immediately perceived by sight

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Upper and lower, right and left, are tangible determinations

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visible ideas suggest tangible situations through learned association

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The retinal image is inverted relative to the object

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: This inversion creates no problem for Berkeley's theory

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: We do not perceive the retinal image at all

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: There is no proper visible image that is either erect or inverted

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: "Erect" and "inverted" are tangible, not visual, notions

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The question of why we see things upright is therefore dissolved

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The traditional geometrical explanations of erect vision are confused

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: External or outward distance is not immediately seen

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Objects are not perceived as being "out there" through sight alone

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Outness is a tangible idea suggested by visual signs

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The moon illusion cannot be explained by optic angles alone

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The horizontal moon appears larger due to associated ideas

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Intervening terrain suggests greater distance for the horizon moon

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Greater suggested distance makes us judge the moon larger

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The zenith moon lacks these intervening distance cues

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The psychological explanation supersedes the geometrical one

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visual ideas are in the mind, not external to it

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The proper objects of sight are mental ideas

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Touch alone gives us the idea of externality

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The tangible world is what we consider the real spatial world

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visual ideas are signs for navigating the tangible world

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Experience connects the two through constant conjunction

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Custom and habit explain the swiftness of perceptual judgments

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: These judgments become so automatic as to seem immediate

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Reflection reveals they are not truly immediate

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: An infant does not perceive distance or magnitude as adults do

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Perceptual learning occurs rapidly in early life

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: A person blind from birth has no ideas of light or color

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Such a person's spatial ideas are entirely tangible

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: If made to see, everything would need to be learned anew

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Their visual field would initially be meaningless

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: They would not connect visible shapes to familiar tangible objects

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The newly sighted would need to learn the visual language from scratch

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: There is no common sensible perceived by both sight and touch

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Number is not a common sensible bridging the senses

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Unity and number are creatures of the mind, not sensed qualities

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The eye does not perceive its own operations

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: We have no direct awareness of optical or physiological processes

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The ideas immediately present in vision contain no necessary reference to distance

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: God could have established different correlations between visual and tangible ideas

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The existing correlations serve human preservation and convenience

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: The visual language is divinely instituted for practical benefit

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Visual signs reliably indicate tangible consequences

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: We learn to read these signs and respond appropriately

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Misinterpretations occur when normal correlations are disrupted

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Optical illusions reveal the learned and inferential nature of perception

topic: An Essay towards a New Theory of Vision
conclusion: Berkeley's theory explains perception without appeal to material substance

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Sensible things are those perceived immediately by the senses

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Heat and cold are sensations, not qualities in external objects

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Intense heat is indistinguishable from pain

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Pain exists only in a perceiving mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Therefore intense heat exists only in a perceiving mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The same argument applies to intense cold

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Moderate degrees of heat and cold are also sensations

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: All degrees of heat exist only in the mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Tastes are sensations perceived by the mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Sweetness and bitterness exist only in the perceiver

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The same item tastes differently to different perceivers

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Odors are sensations existing only in the mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Sounds are sensations, not vibrations in external air

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The sound heard is not identical with motions in the medium

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Colors are sensations perceived by sight

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Colors vary with light, distance, and the perceiver's condition

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: No color is inherent in objects independently of perception

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The distinction between primary and secondary qualities fails

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Extension cannot be conceived apart from some sensible quality

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Extension is always perceived as colored or tangible

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Figure is inseparable from extension

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Motion is inseparable from extension

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Solidity is a sensation of resistance perceived by touch

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Primary qualities are as mind-dependent as secondary qualities

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Size is relative to the perceiver

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The same object appears different sizes to different creatures

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: There is no absolute size existing independently of perception

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Speed of motion is relative to the perceiver's experience

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: All sensible qualities exist only in the mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Sensible things are collections of sensible qualities

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Therefore sensible things exist only in the mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: To be is to be perceived (esse est percipi)

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Material substance is an unintelligible abstraction

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Matter is defined as an unperceived, unthinking substrate

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Such a substrate cannot be conceived coherently

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: We have no idea corresponding to the term "material substance"

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The notion of matter is either contradictory or meaningless

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Material substance cannot be known to exist

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Arguments for matter's existence are fallacious

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The supposition of matter explains nothing

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Perception does not require material causes

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Ideas cannot resemble anything but other ideas

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: An idea cannot resemble an unperceived material thing

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The representative theory of perception fails

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: We perceive ideas immediately, not external objects mediately

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Ideas are passive and inert

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Ideas have no causal power

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: An idea cannot be the cause of another idea

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Only minds or spirits have causal efficacy

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The cause of our sensory ideas must be a mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Our sensory ideas are not caused by our own wills

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: They are caused by another, more powerful mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: This mind is God

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: God immediately produces ideas in our minds

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The regularity of nature is God's consistent mode of operation

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Laws of nature are rules by which God produces ideas

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Natural philosophy studies the grammar of God's visual language

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The order of ideas allows prediction and practical action

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: God's existence is more evident than matter's supposed existence

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Immaterialism provides a direct proof of God's existence

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The materialist hypothesis makes God remote or unnecessary

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Immaterialism makes God intimately present in all perception

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Spirit or mind is the only substance

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Spirit is active, thinking, and perceiving

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: We know our own minds by reflection

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: We have a notion of spirit, though not an idea of it

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Ideas are objects perceived; spirits are perceivers

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Nothing can be like an idea except another idea

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The external world consists of ideas in God's mind

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Sensible objects continue to exist when unperceived by finite minds

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: God perpetually perceives all things

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The tree in the quad exists in God's perception

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Objects have continuous existence through divine perception

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Immaterialism does not deny the reality of the external world

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: It denies only the materialist interpretation of that world

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Common sense is vindicated, not contradicted, by immaterialism

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Ordinary people never believed in material substance

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Material substance is a philosopher's fiction

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Skepticism arises from belief in matter

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: If matter existed, we could never know it

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Immaterialism eliminates the skeptical gap between mind and world

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: We know sensible things directly and immediately

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: There is no veil of perception separating us from reality

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Real things are vivid, orderly, and coherent ideas

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Imaginary things are faint, irregular, and dependent on our will

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The distinction between real and imaginary is preserved

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Natural science remains valid under immaterialism

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Science studies the connections and regularities among ideas

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Causal explanations are descriptions of regular successions

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Mechanistic explanations do not reveal true efficient causes

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Only spirit is a true cause

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Physical explanations describe occasions, not real causes

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The atheist cannot account for the order of nature

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Nature's order requires an intelligent author

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Matter could not produce thought or perception

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Materialism tends toward atheism

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Immaterialism supports theism directly

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: The soul's immortality is more secure without matter

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Immaterialism dissolves many philosophical puzzles

topic: Three Dialogues between Hylas and Philonous
conclusion: Philosophy achieves clarity by abandoning material substance
